title: High U.S. Fuel Exports Are Contributing to $5-a-Gallon Gas
sub_head: The shipments of gasoline, diesel and natural gas are draining already-low inventories and raising prices for U.S. consumers and companies
body:
A rapid rise in American fuel exports this year has helped push gasoline prices to a record $5 a gallon and is pressuring U.S. prices of natural gas, which hit the highest levels in over a decade earlier this month.
In recent months, companies and commodities traders have shipped more U.S. gasoline and diesel to Latin America and other foreign markets, reaping higher prices than the fuel could fetch domestically. They have also sent more liquefied natural gas, or LNG, to Europe after Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine.
